Developers

The development and expansion of Questaal Suite has been led by Mark van Schilfgaarde since its inception. During his time with Ole Anderson’s group at the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Institute (1987-1988), Mark implemented Ole’s new tight-binding formulation of the LMTO-ASA method. This code served as the foundation for the well known Stuttgart LMTO-ASA package, and for many descendents of it, including an ASA-GW code by Aryasetiawan, the original formulation of LDA+U, an early formulation of noncollinear magnetism and of linear response for spin waves, and a the first implementation of excact exchange.

There have been many contributors; a partial list is provided below, in approximate chronological order.

Questaal Developers

Mark van Schilfgaarde (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary Developer

Michael Methfessel (IHP, Germany) Primary developer of the antecedent to the full-potential package.

Tony Paxton (King’s College London, U.K.)
Original Developer of the tight-binding package; ASA Downfolding

John Klepeis (Lawrence Livermore National Lab, California) Additions to the tight-binding package

Walter Lambrecht (Case Western Reserve, Ohio) Added several features to the ASA and full-potential codes, e.g. LDA+U and the optics packages

Athanasios Chantis (Editor, Physical Review) Implementation of the fully relativistic Dirac equation into the ASA package, for studying transport

Takao Kotani (Tottori University, Japan) Primary developer of the GW package

Sergei Faleev Primary developer of Quasiparticle Self-Consistency in GW, and of nonequilibrium Keldysh transport

Derek Stewart Transmission in the Landauer-Buttiker formalism (layer Green’s function), maintainer of LMSuite website

Kiril Belashchenko (University of Nebraska) CPA, Spin-Orbit Coupling, in the Green’s function package

Liqin Ke (Ames Lab, Iowa) magnetic linear response, magnetic symmetry, Empty sphere finder

Dimitar Pashov (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of the tight-binding package and the Jigsaw Puzzle Orbitals. Primary Questaal suite maintainer.

Alena Vishina (King’s College London, U.K.) Self-consistent fully relativistic Dirac equation; relativistic linear response

Paolo Pisanti (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of interface between this package and Rutger’s DMFT

Lorenzo Sponza (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of a QSGW+DMFT implementation

Nicola Bonini (King’s College London, U.K.) Supervises implementation of phonons and the electron-phonon interaction into the GW package

Savio Laricchia (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of implementation of phonons and the electron-phonon interaction into the GW package

Myrta Gruening (Queen’s University Belfast, U.K.) Supervises the addition of ladder diagrams to the GW package

Brian Cunningham (Queen’s University Belfast, U.K.) Primary developer of ladder diagrams added to GW by Bethe-Salpeter.

Pooya Azarhoosh (King’s College London, U.K.) Additions to the optics packaged; involved in code dissemination and documentation

Scott McKechnie (King’s College London, U.K.) Electric Fields for Spin orbit coupling; involved in redesign of input system and documentation

Lewis Christiansen (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of Questaal web site, with Gergely Kantor

Gergely Kantor (King’s College London, U.K.) Primary developer of Questaal web site, with Lewis Christiansen

Ben Kaube (Imperial College London, U.K.) Designed an ACX?? interface to the Questaal package; (frozen) phonon contribution to dielectric optical properties
